bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, January 12, 1941

div1.p: Truby suggests several corrections for Hench's article. He maintains that Kissinger volunteered before Moran and mentions his plans to work on his own paper. He invites Hench to visit him.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, January 12, 1941

opener.dateline:
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
Jan. 12/41

div1.p:
Your lengthy and most welcome
letter (via. Air Mail) came this morning and
I have also received the W. & J. program and
your letter of the 30th ult-

I think one of my letters to you must
have gone astray for I acknowledged
receipt of the first W. & J. programs you sent
and also asked you some questions which
I felt sure you would promptly answer-
That was probably about the middle of Nov.
As I had also sent you two letters
which should have been awaiting your
return from the East (About Nov 1st) I could
not imagine why I did not hear from
you. So I wrote again, early in Dec.,
and then when I did not hear from
you after about 13 days I was really
disturbed. Then I wrote a Christmas letter
to our grand old friend Kean and
asked him what had happened as you
failed to answer my letters. I think
I told him, though, that I had received
the W. & J. program-

The brochure from W. & J. has arrived
and I am, of course, much pleased to have
Ac
T
2
it. I have been over it with a “fine bath
comb” and in your article, which is splendid,
there are a fromtwo mistakes which should be
corrected before it is republished, as I suppose
it will be- Both occur in the quotation from
my story:- (1) Lazear was taken sick on Sept 16th not
August. (2) “On the same day (Sept 18) his house
was immediately sealed up & fumigated.” That
really should read. On the next day (Sept 19th)
or better, yet, change the preceeding sentence
so that it would read thus:- He was thenIn the morning (Sept 19)
he was carried on a litter to theour Yellow Fever hospital
across the La Playa railroad track from the Post Hospital.
On the same day (Sept. 19) his house was immediately
sealed up & fumigated.

When I telegraphed you a few days before
you started for W. & J. I perpetuated that error
in dates as I had your mms, before me.
Within a day or so I realized the error
and wrote you about it (About Nov 1st)
My retained copy of my m.m.s. shows the correct
dates so I do not know how the mistake was
made- Sometime I will discuss some of
the other details of your article- I concur
in almost all of it.

I did not know until recently that
there was any controversy on between Moran
& Kissinger. I obtained Kissingers address
from you hoping to get a few points
cleared up, by him and he then told me
of Moran's claims. Kissinger gave
me no help and I think I told you
3
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
in one of my letters how surprised
I was at his aparent senility.
However, I am prepared to convince you,
later on, that Kissinger did volunteer
to Reed first and that Moran followed
him a day or two later.

Naturally I have not followed the
various controversies. All I know about
them is what I have picked up in my
casual reading. Of course I have devoured
everything that came my way on the subject-
Agramonte's letter to Dr. Hemmeter is most
interesting. This and other inclosures,
I (including photos). I will return as,
soon as I can study them and write
out my comments. I am awfully handicapped
by not having a Stenographer. I could
dictate by the hour on this subject. However,
if you can read my writing without
too much trouble it won't matter, for
I, personally, have plenty of time to do it
this way-

Your comments on my M. M. S. are fine
and very much appreciated. I knew that
many items were out of their chronological
order and that the whole thing was very
messy. On that account I hesitated to
Ac
T
(4)
let you see it, but General Kean urged
me to do so as he felt sure it contained
much info. you wanted. When I received
your first letter early in July '40,. I had
the article written out in long hand. It could
not be sent out in that shape so I had the
parts about Lazear typed and sent to you.
Then Kean urged me to have it typed
so that he could see it. He said that he
was 80 and that life at that age was uncertain.
So I had the original, crude thing, copied-
Now with the benefit of your constructive
criticism I can go at it again, and
then with the help of a good stenographer,
I think it can be properly arranged
and dressed up so that it wont be too bad-
The original mms. was much longer and
I eliminated many things that I felt would
be of no interest. I still have some of
the original pen pages and when I return
my your papers, will inclose the part
which covers your question as to why
Walter Reed became a bit interested in me.

I have absolutely no plans about publishing
my story. I appreciate your suggestions.
I agree that our stories are entirely
of a different scope and nature. You are the logical
man to sift the thing out thoroughly and
I am anxious to give you every possible
help. I am not hostile to any of the
people who are, or have been, mixed up
in the controversies. I do know a lot
5
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
about Agramonte and on that account did
not want to write the story at all. I know
much more than I have told on paper
and when I see you will give you
an earfull (all confidential, however) Kean knew
it, too, when he wrote O'Reilly's article for the
Senate Document. There is no desire on
my part to make any of it public, unless
there is a real demand on the part of
others, including yourself, for the facts
as I know them. The things I know have
not been distorted by controversies, discussions
or anything else. They are as clear to
me now as they have been since they
were originally observed- No one was more
shocked than I was when Agramonte
began to talk (about 1908)

I know of no reason why I will
not be able to see you out here in March.
Of course I am still subject to call
for active duty in the Army. I doubt,
however, that I will be molested
unless things get out of hand in
the Medical Dept. If the War Dept. starts
off the main portion of the draft until
late spring I think nothing very important
will happen. If, however, they fill up
the unfinished camps with thousands of new
Ac
T
men during the next three months anything
can and probably will happen- Everything
will be new and the personnel all inexperiences.
Under such conditions epidemics of severe
influenza, Cerebro Spinal- measles, etc
would rage-

I do hope you can come out here
and if so plan to stay long enough
to listen to what I can tell you and
to see what I have. I have a few
photos and other things that will be of
interest and besides I think I can help
you to find invaluable material in Washington.
You must come!

In the next week or two I will work
up the question answers to the questions
in your long letter and mail everything
back to you.

Again with many thanks for
your very acceptable and comprehensive
review of my paper,

closer.seg:
P. S. I wont send this Air Mail as
it is very stormy between here and Salt
Lake, Planes may be grounded and
not be any too reliable
